title: Hubble observes dead star devouring Pluto-like object
summary:
With help from NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope in low-Earth orbit, scientists recently observed a Pluto-like…
The post Hubble observes dead star devouring Pluto-like object appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: With help from NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope in low-Earth orbit, scientists recently observed a Pluto-like object being “eaten” by its host star. The hungry star is a white dwarf — the dense, stellar core left behind after a low-mass star dies and blows away its outer layers. The white dwarf observed by Hubble is about the size of Earth but much heavier, at around half the mass of our Sun. The white dwarf was likely once a Sun-like star that hosted a suite of planets and circumstellar disks similar to the Kuiper Belt. As the fragments fall onto the white dwarf, the star accretes them, emitting primarily ultraviolet light and very little visible light. The team is planning to continue their observations of hungry white dwarfs in the infrared with the James Webb Space Telescope. title: What’s Happening in Space Policy September 28-October 4, 2025
summary: Here is SpacePolicyOnline.com’s list of space policy events for the week of September 28-October 4, 2025 and any insight we can offer about them. The congressional schedule is in flux. […]
detailed_news: Congress has until midnight on Tuesday to reach a deal or there will be a partial government shutdown. President Trump agreed to meet tomorrow with congressional leaders of both parties. House Speaker Mike Johnson decided to keep the House out of session until at least October 1, forcing the Senate to either agree to his bill or cause a shutdown. NASA astronaut Chris Williams is getting ready to launch to the ISS on Soyuz MS-28 next month. Williams will be at Johnson Space Center and participate in a news conference to discuss what he’ll do during his eight-month assignment. Wednesday not only is the beginning of FY2026, but the 67th anniversary of when NASA opened its doors.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch 24 Starlink satellites on Falcon 9 rocket from Vandenberg SFB
summary: The Starlink 11-20 mission will see SpaceX’s Falcon 9 rocket fly on a south-easterly trajectory upon departure from Vandenberg Space Force Base. Liftoff from pad 4E is scheduled for 4:32 p.m. PDT (7:32 p.m. EDT / 2332 UTC).
detailed_news: The Starlink 11-20 mission is SpaceX’s 88th mission supporting its megaconstellation this year. The satellites were manufactured by Northrop Grumman and will provide both commercial broadband connectivity and military satellite communications in the northern polar region. If successful, this will be the 154th touch down for this vessel and the 513th booster landing to date.

summary: The Starlink 11-20 mission will see SpaceX’s Falcon 9 rocket fly on a south-easterly trajectory upon departure from Vandenberg Space Force Base. Liftoff from pad 4E is scheduled for 4:32 p.m. PDT (7:32 p.m. EDT / 2332 UTC).

title: Galactic Energy secures $336 million, nears debut of new reusable and solid rockets
summary:
Beijing-based Galactic Energy has raised what appears China’s largest disclosed round for a launch startup as it nears orbital test flights of new rockets.
The post Galactic Energy secures $336 million, nears debut of new reusable and solid rockets appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Beijing-based Galactic Energy has raised what appears China’s largest disclosed round for a launch startup. The company announced Series D financing of 2.4 billion yuan ($336 million) in a statement Sept. 28. The funding will be used for the Pallas series of reusable liquid propellant launchers and the Ceres-2 solid rocket. The rocket is an upgraded version of the Ceres-1. Launch will now take place “at an appropriate time” in the near future. The rocket was earlier slated for a test flight in the first half of the year. The Ceres-2 will have a payload capacity of 1,600 kg to 500-km LEO, and 1,300 kg to500-km SSO.

title: IAI’s Game-Changing Communication Satellites: Revolutionizing Global Connectivity

authors.name: Tsuri Shemer – IAI Space Marketing & Business Development

summary:

The post IAI’s Game-Changing Communication Satellites: Revolutionizing Global Connectivity appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Israel Aerospace Industries (IAI) has emerged as a trailblazer, pushing the boundaries of satellite technology and transforming the way we communicate. IAI’s compact communication satellites provide unprecedented coverage, ensuring connectivity even in the most remote and underserved areas. These satellites are designed to be resilient against space debris and solar radiation, ensuring uninterrupted operations and longevity. IAI is redefining the future of space. IAI delivers turnkey, space-proven solutions tailored to mission success. Come meet IAI’s satellite experts at IAC 2025 – Booth #599, or contact us at iai-mth-sms@iai.co.il.

Blue Origin’s goal is to scale up to “approximately weekly’ launches, enabled by three new New Shepard vehicles. title: Purdue University to fly dedicated suborbital research mission with Virgin Galactic
summary:
Purdue University will conduct a dedicated suborbital research flight with Virgin Galactic in 2027 carrying a professor, student and alumni.
The post Purdue University to fly dedicated suborbital research mission with Virgin Galactic appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Purdue University will conduct a dedicated suborbital research flight with Virgin Galactic in 2027. The flight, carrying five people, will be the first dedicated crewed sub Orbital research mission by a university. It will be led by Steven Collicott, a professor of aerospace engineering at Purdue. “I think the science leading the way in science is going to be pretty intensely exciting, and things happen pretty quick,” Collicott said. “That’s the only chance I’ll get to look out the windows. I look forward to that.”

title: NASA Marshall director steps down
summary:
The director of NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center has abruptly stepped down, becoming the third NASA center director to leave in recent months.
The post NASA Marshall director steps down appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Joseph Pelfrey announced he would no longer serve as director of the Alabama center. He did not give a specific reason for his departure but suggested he was leaving to allow NASA leadership to select its own choice. He is the third NASA center director to leave in recent months.

title: China boosts broadband, IoT and weather satellite fleets with flurry of launches
summary:
A flurry of launch activity has seen China add to an Internet of Things constellation, loft new broadband satellites and boost its weather satellite fleet.
The post China boosts broadband, IoT and weather satellite fleets with flurry of launches appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: A Long March 6A lifted off at 8:40 a.m. Eastern (1240 UTC) Sept. 27 from Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center in north China. The mission payloads are believed to be the 11th batch of Guowang broadband megaconstellation project. The launch came less than a day after China added to its Fengyun series of meteorological satellites. China is closing in on a new national record for launches in a calendar year ( currently 68, set in 2024 ). Of the launches, 56 have been successful, with the only failure coming in August. The next launch out of China is expected to be a Long March 2D rocket launching from Jiuquan early Sept. 29 UTC.

title: From City Lights to Moonlight: NASA Training Shows How Urban Parks Can Connect Communities with Space Science
summary: When you think about national park and public land astronomy programs, you might picture remote locations far from city lights. But a recent NASA Earth to Sky training, funded by NASA’s Science Activation Program, challenges that assumption, demonstrating how urban parks, wildlife refuges, museums, and green spaces can be incredible venues for connecting communities with […]
detailed_news: NASA Earth to Sky partnered with the National Park Service and U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to deliver an innovative astronomy training program. The training empowered participants by affirming that everyone is an effective stargazer and night sky storyteller. The course also created a lasting community connection to NASA. Earth to Sky works with park interpreters and nonformal educators to share NASA space science. Learn more about how Science Activation connects NASA science experts, real content, and experiences with community leaders to do science in ways that activate minds and promote deeper understanding of our world and beyond.

detailed_news: Melwood Horticultural Training Center Inc. of Upper Marlboro, Maryland, will provide custodial, janitorial, landscaping, and recycling services for the agency's Goddard Space Flight Center. The contract includes one 12-month base period and up to four 12- months options with a potential contract value of approximately $36 million.

The Harlow Shapley Visiting Lectureship Program has a history dating back to the 1950s, when it provided support for a scientist to give a series of astronomy-themed lectures. NASA's Parker Solar Probe became the first spacecraft to fly through the corona of the Sun. NASA’s Juno spacecraft entered orbit around Jupiter in 2016, the first explorer to peer below the planet's dense clouds. title: Lunar Challenge Winner Tests Technology in NASA Thermal Vacuum Chamber
summary: By Savannah Bullard One year after winning second place in NASA’s Break the Ice Lunar Challenge, members of the small business Starpath visited NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama, as part of their prize opportunity to test their upgraded lunar regolith excavation and transportation rover in the center’s 20-foot thermal vacuum chamber. The […]
detailed_news: Small business Starpath won second place in NASA’s Break the Ice Lunar Challenge. The company built a four-wheeled rover capable of excavating, collecting, and hauling material under extremely harsh environmental conditions that simulate the lunar South Pole. Starpath staff spent about three days at NASA Marshall in August, testing their robot with excavation and mobility trials while collecting data.

title: 2025-2026 DWU: High School Engineering Challenge
summary: 2025-2026 DWU: High School Engineering Challenge Challenge Materials Challenge Materials The 2025 Challenge Materials are coming soon. Register now to get copies as soon as they are released. Overview: What is an Uncrewed Aircraft System?  An uncrewed aircraft system (UAS) can be defined as an aircraft without an operator or flight crew onboard the aircraft […]
detailed_news: An uncrewed aircraft system (UAS) can be defined as an aircraft without an operator or flight crew onboard the aircraft itself. Their civilian/commercial uses include aerial photography/filming, agriculture, communications, conservation/wildlife monitoring, damage assessment/infrastructure inspection, law enforcement/security, search and rescue, weather monitoring and research. The 2025-2026 Dream with Us Design Challenge will focus on Uncrewed Aircraft Systems (UAS) and implementing UAS into the agriculture industry. This year’s mission is to develop an uncrewed aircraft system that will detect agricultural pests. Teams will work together with coaches and mentors to identify what is needed while pursuing the completion of this challenge. Agricultural pests cost billions of dollars in losses across the globe every year. The strategic use of uncrewed aircraft is making significant impacts in reducing the impact of agricultural pests. Properly implemented, agricultural output can be increased while also reducing resource use. This year’s challenge is to design Uncrewed Aircraft Systems. The successful proposal should include an estimate of the project’s budget as well as the potential cost savings. It is strongly recommended that teams conduct their own research on the topic to answer the following questions. The basic purpose of a concept of operations is to describe the characteristics of a system from the viewpoint of a user. The purpose of a detect-and-avoid system is to be able to sense objects that might pose a threat, detect if an object becomes a conflict (potential collision) During flight, the uncrewed aircraft may be operating near manned aircraft. Safety of people in other aircraft are a priority. Having a communications system that can handle the necessary tasks is essential. Any UAS performing remote sensing require a variety of roles to be fulfilled by personnel on the ground to ensure safe and successful completion of the mission. Different aircraft and application types will require different roles and different numbers of ground support personnel. Use this experience to better understand what roles would be required, at a minimum, to create your design from conception to final delivery. Cost of Personnel is the total costs for all personnel required to fly, reload, refuel, repair the UAV during the mission. This cost also includes the personnel cost during the time to complete the preparation and post-mission. To calculate fixed costs you must add up the costs of all components of your aircraft. For the Dream with Us 2025-2026 challenge, your team is asked to develop a set of materials to make the case to support the utilization of UAS. There may be a variety of types of media used depending on the plan developed by the team. Infographics are a method for communicating a lot of information using images words and numbers in an easier to understand way. The Scoring Rubric should be used as the headings in your Engineering Design Notebook. On the getting started section above, you will also find software, webinars, and a survey. Teams of judges will evaluate your work based on what you submit in your engineering design notebook.

title: 2025-2026 DWU: Middle School Aviation Challenge
summary: 2025-2026 DWU: Middle School Aviation Challenge Challenge Theme AgAir: Integrating UAS into the Agriculture Industry The agricultural industry is an important part of life in the US and around the world by providing food, fuel, economic development, and more. It has been increasingly important to strategically improve the agricultural industry to continue to provide for […]
detailed_news: The 2025/2026 Dream with Us Design Challenge for middle and high school students opens September 26, 2025. Middle school teams of 2-4 members will create a new design or improve current capabilities of uncrewed aerial vehicles (UAVs) to improve areas of agriculture. Designs are conceptual and do not need to be created with any type of technical software. The middle school challenge is open to all children in grades 6 – 8 who are attending public, private, parochial, and home schools in the United States of America and children of U.S. military members stationed overseas. The high school module is for participants in grades 9 – 12. The challenge is limited to one entry per team. Entries will be evaluated based on impact, practicality, originality, and how well the idea is communicated. Contest officials will then select the top submissions to a finalist panel. Winners will be publicly announced on the Dream with Us Design Challenge webpage no later than March 1 st , 2026. The 2025/2026 Dream with Us Design Challenge for middle and high school students opens September 26, 2025. The submission period for middle school entrants begins September 26,. 2025, and concludes on December 31, 2025, at 11:59 pm ET. A virtual educator professional development webinar will be scheduled for October 2025 that will include details about the challenge. The middle school challenge is open to all children in grades 6 – 8 who are attending public, private, parochial, and home schools in the United States of America. The high school module is for participants in grades 9 – 12. Entries will be evaluated based on impact, practicality, originality, and how well the idea is communicated. Contest officials will then select the top submissions to a finalist panel.

Since the space station became operational in November 2000, crew members have produced hundreds of thousands of images of the land, oceans, and atmosphere of Earth, and even of the Moon.

summary: Join observers from around the world on Saturday, Oct. 4, for NASA’s International Observe the Moon Night. Launching in early 2026, the mission […]
detailed_news: International Observe the Moon Night is Saturday, Oct. 4. The Moon will be in a waxing gibbous phase, with most of its face lit up by the Sun. Moon observers will see large, dark patches on the Moon called “maria,” or “seas” in Latin.

They will also be fought openly in orbit,” said Pistorius. “That’s […]

title: I Am Artemis: Diamond St. John
summary: Listen to this audio excerpt from Diamond St. John, engineer working on the Artemis III heat shield for the Orion Program at Lockheed Martin: For four-generations, Diamond St. John’s family has been supporting human spaceflight at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Now, she’s continuing the family legacy that reaches back to Apollo —helping return […]
detailed_news: Diamond St. John is an engineer with Lockheed Martin supporting Orion, NASA’s spacecraft built to carry crew to the Moon and return them safely to Earth on Artemis missions. She specializes in the production of Orion's heat shield. As one of the most important elements of the spacecraft, the heat shield is responsible for protecting the astronauts from the nearly 5,000 degrees Fahrenheit temperatures as they re-enter Earth's atmosphere.

title: Sierra Space’s Dream Chaser debut mission delayed again, no longer docking to station
summary: The space plane was brought to the Kennedy Space Center in May 2024 with plans to launch later that year. Now, its first flight is no earlier than late 2026.
detailed_news: Sierra Space's Dream Chaser cargo space plane will no longer see a docking with the International Space Station. The space plane is now scheduled to launch on its inaugural flight no earlier than late 2026. Instead of docking to the ISS, the vehicle named Tenacity will now conduct a free-flyer mission. The Dream Chaser space plane was originally imagined as a crewed vehicle that could fly as part of NASA’s Commercial Crew Program. The cargo version of the vehicle has been in the works for years. In May 2024, Tenacity arrived at the Space Systems Processing Facility (SSPF) at NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Florida.

title: NASA’s contract overhaul puts Dream Chaser’s ISS future in jeopardy
summary:
NASA has announced significant modifications to its contract with Sierra Space for the Dream Chaser…
The post NASA’s contract overhaul puts Dream Chaser’s ISS future in jeopardy appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: NASA has announced significant modifications to its contract with Sierra Space for the Dream Chaser spacecraft. This development raises serious questions about whether the long-awaited ‘baby shuttle’ will ever fulfill its original promise of delivering cargo to the orbiting laboratory. The Dream Chaser, a winged reusable spacecraft designed for atmospheric reentry and runway landings, has been plagued by delays. Sierra Space's Dream Chaser spacecraft has been in development since the 1990s. The first flight-ready vehicle, DC-101 Tenacity, arrived at Kennedy Space Center in May 2024 for final pre-launch preparations. With the ISS scheduled for deorbiting in 2031, the window for completing seven missions was already narrowing. Sierra Space is working with NASA on a demo of the Dream Chaser spacecraft. The shuttle-like craft could be used for resupply missions to the ISS. Sierra Space is also contributing hardware to Orbital Reef, a project led by Blue Origin. The company hopes the demo will get Dream Chaser off the ground.

title: Dream Chaser Slips to End of 2026 for Free-Flyer Demo Only
summary: NASA said today they are requiring Sierra Space to conduct a free flyer demonstration of the Dream Chaser spacecraft before the first cargo mission to the International Space Station. The […]
detailed_news: Dream Chaser has yet to make a spaceflight after more than a decade of development and the demonstration flight is not even expected until the end of 2026. The contractual requirement that NASA buy seven cargo flights is also eliminated. Sierra Space called the changes a “strategic transition.” Sierra Space called it a “strategic transition” as they seek “to preserve the exceptional potential of Dream Chaser as a national asset” They added the changes aim ‘to provide Sierra Space with flexibility to address the nation’s most pressing National Security Space challenges’

title: NASA modifies Dream Chaser ISS cargo contract as Sierra Space shifts to defense work
summary:
Sierra Space and NASA have sharply revised a contract to use the company’s Dream Chaser vehicle to deliver cargo to the ISS as the company pivots to defense applications.
The post NASA modifies Dream Chaser ISS cargo contract as Sierra Space shifts to defense work appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Sierra Space will fly a single "free flight demonstration" mission, scheduled for late 2026. The contract no longer specifies a set number of cargo missions to the station. The company has recently emphasized defense work, including satellites for the Space Development Agency. Sierra Space was one of three companies that won contracts in 2016 to deliver cargo to the ISS. NASA has obligated $1.43 billion to Sierra Space under CRS-2 to date. That compares to $3.21 billion for Northrop Grumman and $ 3.37 billion for SpaceX. A NASA spokesperson declined to disclose the current value of Sierra Space’s contract.

title: Sierra’s Dream Chaser is starting to resemble a nightmare
summary: "Development of new space transportation systems is difficult."
detailed_news: The Dream Chaser spaceplane has been under development for two decades. On Thursday, NASA said the first flight of the winged spacecraft will no longer berth with the International Space Station. Rather, the space agency said, the Dream Chaser program would be "best served" by a free flight demonstration. Ars is a trusted source in a sea of information. You don’t need to know everything, only what’s important. With our unique combination of technical savvy and wide-ranging interest in the technological arts and sciences, we can help you understand the world around you.

title: NASA Flights Study Cosmic Ray Effects for Air, Future Space Travelers
summary: Recent airborne science flights to Greenland are improving NASA’s understanding of space weather by measuring radiation exposure to air travelers and validating global radiation maps used in flight path planning. This unique data also has value beyond the Earth as a celestial roadmap for using the same instrumentation to monitor radiation levels for travelers entering […]

title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch 24 Starlink satellites on Falcon 9 rocket from Vandenberg
summary: The Starlink 17-11 mission includes the 475th launch of a flight-proven booster. SpaceX is targeting liftoff from pad 4E at Vandenberg Space Force Base at 9:17 p.m. PDT (12:17 a.m. EDT / 0417 UTC).
detailed_news: SpaceX is preparing to launch its third Falcon 9 rocket in less than 41 hours. On deck is the flight of the Starlink 17-11 mission, which will take off from Vandenberg Space Force Base. The rocket will deploy 24 of SpaceX’s Starlink V2 Mini broadband internet satellites into low Earth orbit.

title: SpaceX, Blue Origin, Stoke, and others make major progress on Cape launch facilities
summary:
The two spaceport launch facilities in the Cape Canaveral area — NASA’s Kennedy Space Center…
The post SpaceX, Blue Origin, Stoke, and others make major progress on Cape launch facilities appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: The two spaceport launch facilities in the Cape Canaveral area are on the verge of even bigger changes than have been seen in the last few years. SpaceX is making significant progress on its Starship program facilities. Blue Origin is showing signs of progress toward launching its second New Glenn rocket. Stoke Space, based in the Pacific Northwest, and Relativity, headquartered in Long Beach, California, plan to join SpaceX and Blue Origin in the spaceflight market with their own reusability-enabled launch vehicles. SpaceX NSF’s flyover imagery shows Starship-related progress underway at multiple sites. The Roberts Road facility is where pad items, both large and small, are fabricated or delivered. Five Starship tower segments were spotted at Roberts Road, with four of them completed, a fifth nearing completion, and work started on a sixth. SpaceX continues to make progress on the massive Giga Bay, which will be about half the size of NASA’s Vehicle Assembly Building (VAB) Workers have poured a large amount of concrete and are installing four tower cranes in what will be the transfer aisles. SpaceX is also busy with changes to its existing Falcon 9 launch pad at SLC-40. Blue Origin Exploration Park is undergoing continued work and expansion. New Glenn Transporter was seen moving past the VAB on Sept. 21, which could indicate a possible rollout of New Glenn Flight 2’s Glenn Stage 1 first stage as soon as Oct. 5. Workers have conducted launch checkouts at LC-36 with the New Glenn Simulator in the meantime. Blue Origin also recently assembled and tested a large deployable sunshield at Lunar Plant 1, which will protect both Lunar Transporter and the Blue Moon Mk2 crewed lunar lander. NSF also showed progress on the NASA Artemis program’s ML2 parked by the VAB. The ML2 will not be used for the next two Artemis missions but will be needed for Artemis IV and subsequent missions, if these missions are flown. The SLS rocket for Artemis II is almost completely stacked with validation and checkouts complete, but still requires stacking of the Orion spacecraft and its launch abort system tower.

title: Artemis 2 could launch as soon as February
summary:
NASA’s Artemis 2 mission around the moon could launch as soon as early February, as both agency officials and the mission’s four-person crew say they are ready for the flight.
The post Artemis 2 could launch as soon as February appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: NASA's Artemis 2 mission around the moon could launch as soon as early February. Officials reaffirmed the current schedule, which calls for a launch no later than April 2026. Artemis 2 will be a roughly 10-day mission, beginning with a day in an elliptical Earth orbit. Four American and Canadian astronauts flying on Artemis 2 say they are ready for the mission. “There is no frustration in what we would perceive, from the outside looking in, as delays,” mission commander Reid Wiseman said. The crew also announced the Orion spacecraft’s name: Integrity.

title: L3Harris looks to scale production of hybrid satcom radios after successful Air Force tests
summary:
Under a partnership with Amazon’s Kuiper, L3Harris would bring the broadband service to military users
The post L3Harris looks to scale production of hybrid satcom radios after successful Air Force tests appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: L3Harris says it has successfully demonstrated a satellite-based radio system. The system allows military aircraft to tap commercial space broadband services. The radios are in limited use with a handful of military customers. L3Harris is working with Amazon’s Project Kuiper, which is building a broadband constellation. title: NASA Opens 2026 Human Lander Challenge for Life Support Systems, More
summary: NASA’s 2026 Human Lander Challenge is seeking ideas from college and university students to help evolve and transform technologies for life support and environmental control systems. These systems are critical for sustainable, long-duration human spaceflight missions to the Moon, Mars, and beyond. The Human Lander Challenge supports NASA’s efforts to foster innovative solutions to a […]

title: NASA, Sierra Space Modify Commercial Resupply Services Contract
summary: In 2016, NASA awarded a Commercial Resupply Services-2 contract to Sierra Space, formerly part of Sierra Nevada Corporation, to resupply the International Space Station with its Dream Chaser spaceplane and companion Shooting Star cargo module. As part of its contract, Sierra Space was awarded a minimum seven flights, and the agency previously issued firm-fixed price task orders for […]

title: 3-in-1 Launch
summary: A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket lifts off from NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Sept. 24, 2025, carrying three missions that will investigate the Sun’s influence across the solar system. NASA’s IMAP (Interstellar Mapping and Acceleration Probe), the agency’s Carruthers Geocorona Observatory, and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s (NOAA) Space Weather Follow On–Lagrange 1 (SWFO-L1) […]

title: NASA-ISRO Satellite Sends First Radar Images of Earth’s Surface
summary: The NISAR (NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperture Radar) Earth-observing radar satellite’s first images of our planet’s surface are in, and they offer a glimpse of things to come as the joint mission between NASA and ISRO (Indian Space Research Organisation) approaches full science operations later this year. “Launched under President Trump in conjunction with India, NISAR’s first […]

title: NASA & STEM Learning Ecosystems: Opportunities & Benefits for Everyone
summary: STEM learning ecosystems are intentionally designed, community-wide partnerships that enable all Americans to actively participate in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) throughout their lifetimes. Lifelong STEM learning helps people build critical knowledge and skills, access economic opportunities, drive innovation, and make informed decisions in a changing world. STEM learning ecosystems draw on expertise and […]
